\section{preprocess.pre\_process module}
\label{\detokenize{docs/source/preprocess:module-preprocess.pre_process}}\label{\detokenize{docs/source/preprocess:preprocess-pre-process-module}}\index{preprocess.pre\_process (module)@\spxentry{preprocess.pre\_process}\spxextra{module}}
Loads the Data from the .wav music files, preprocesses it and saves it as numpy array.
Main Pre processing Steps:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Loading the individual track in time domain using \sphinxtitleref{Data} object.

\item {} 
Converting the loaded track to mono.

\item {} 
Transforming it to frequency domain using \sphinxtitleref{STFT} object which does Short Time Fourier Transformation.

\item {} 
Normalises it by scaling it between 0 to 1 giving 0 to lowest values and 1 to highest values.

\item {} 
Repeats the steps 1 to 3 for sources and than for scaling it scales the sources relative to the mixture.

\end{itemize}
\index{main() (in module preprocess.pre\_process)@\spxentry{main()}\spxextra{in module preprocess.pre\_process}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{docs/source/preprocess:preprocess.pre_process.main}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{preprocess.pre\_process.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{main}}}{}{}
Main method of pre-processing the data and saving it as numpy files

\end{fulllineitems}



\section{preprocess.preprocess\_tools module}
\label{\detokenize{docs/source/preprocess:module-preprocess.preprocess_tools}}\label{\detokenize{docs/source/preprocess:preprocess-preprocess-tools-module}}\index{preprocess.preprocess\_tools (module)@\spxentry{preprocess.preprocess\_tools}\spxextra{module}}
This module contains the tools used for pre-processing music tracks to be feed into the neural network.
\index{STFT (class in preprocess.preprocess\_tools)@\spxentry{STFT}\spxextra{class in preprocess.preprocess\_tools}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{docs/source/preprocess:preprocess.preprocess_tools.STFT}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class }}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{preprocess.preprocess\_tools.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{STFT}}}{\emph{sr=44100}, \emph{n\_per\_seg=4096}, \emph{n\_overlap=3072}}{}
Bases: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{object}}
\begin{description}
\item[{Short Time Fourier Transform(STFT)}] \leavevmode
Transforms time series data into frequency domain

\end{description}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Variables}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{sr}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{int}}) \textendash{} sampling rate

\item {}

\item {}

\end{description}\end{quote}
\index{\_\_init\_\_() (preprocess.preprocess\_tools.STFT method)@\spxentry{\_\_init\_\_()}\spxextra{preprocess.preprocess\_tools.STFT method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{docs/source/preprocess:preprocess.preprocess_tools.STFT.__init__}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{\_\_init\_\_}}}{\emph{sr=44100}, \emph{n\_per\_seg=4096}, \emph{n\_overlap=3072}}{}
Constructor
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{sr}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{int}}) \textendash{} sampling rate

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{n\_per\_seg}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{int}}) \textendash{} window size for computing STFT

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{n\_overlap}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{int}}) \textendash{} overlap samples for each window shift

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{istft() (preprocess.preprocess\_tools.STFT method)@\spxentry{istft()}\spxextra{preprocess.preprocess\_tools.STFT method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{docs/source/preprocess:preprocess.preprocess_tools.STFT.istft}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{istft}}}{\emph{X}}{}
Generates the inverse STFT of frequency domain data.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{X}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ndarray}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{, }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{shape}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{(}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{nb\_frames}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{, }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{nb\_bins}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{, }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{nb\_channels}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{)}}) \textendash{} audio signal in time domain.

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
\sphinxstylestrong{data} \textendash{} audio signal in time domain.

\item[{Return type}] \leavevmode
ndarray, shape(nb\_channels, nb\_samples)

\end{description}\end{quote}
\subsubsection*{Notes}

inverse STFT is given by:
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}x(m) = \frac{ \sum_{t}x_{t}(m)h(h-tH) }{ \sum_{t} h^{2}(m-tH) }\end{split}
\end{equation*}
Where the parameters represents following:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\(x(m)\) is retrieved signal

\item {} 
\(h\) is window

\item {} 
\(t\) is time of the signal

\item {} 
\(H\) = \sphinxtitleref{n\_per\_seg} - \sphinxtitleref{n\_overlap} is hop size of the signal

\end{itemize}


\sphinxstrong{See also:}

\begin{description}
\item[{{\hyperref[\detokenize{docs/source/preprocess:preprocess.preprocess_tools.STFT.stft}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{stft()}}}}}}] \leavevmode
STFT (Short Time Fourier Transformation)

\end{description}



\end{fulllineitems}

\index{stft() (preprocess.preprocess\_tools.STFT method)@\spxentry{stft()}\spxextra{preprocess.preprocess\_tools.STFT method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{docs/source/preprocess:preprocess.preprocess_tools.STFT.stft}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{stft}}}{\emph{audio\_data}}{}
Generates the STFT of time series data
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{audio\_data}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ndarray}}) \textendash{} shape(nb\_channels, nb\_samples)
audio signal in time domain.

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
\sphinxstylestrong{data} \textendash{} shape(nb\_frames, nb\_bins, nb\_channels)
STFT of the signal.

\item[{Return type}] \leavevmode
ndarray

\end{description}\end{quote}
\subsubsection*{Notes}

STFT of signal \(x(m)\) is given by:
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}x(t) = x(m)h(m - tH)\end{split}
\end{equation*}
Where the parameters represents following:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\(x(m)\) is signal

\item {} 
\(t\) is time

\item {} 
\(h(m)\) is window

\item {} 
\(H\) = \sphinxtitleref{n\_per\_seg} - \sphinxtitleref{n\_overlap} is hop size of the signal

\end{itemize}


\sphinxstrong{See also:}

\begin{description}
\item[{{\hyperref[\detokenize{docs/source/preprocess:preprocess.preprocess_tools.STFT.istft}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{istft()}}}}}}] \leavevmode
inverse STFT (Short Time Fourier Transformation)

\end{description}



\end{fulllineitems}


\end{fulllineitems}

\index{scale() (preprocess.preprocess\_tools.Scaler method)@\spxentry{scale()}\spxextra{preprocess.preprocess\_tools.Scaler method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{docs/source/preprocess:preprocess.preprocess_tools.Scaler.scale}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{scale}}}{\emph{X}, \emph{boundary=None}}{}
Scales the magnitude of STFT(Spectrogram)

Firstly, it clips the spectrogramic data to percentile bounds
to reduce the impact of noise in order to get unconsistent result.

Lastly, it normalises or scales the clipped data to values between 0 and 1.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{X}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ndarray}}) \textendash{} magnitude of stft

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{boundary}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ndarray}}) \textendash{} boundary to which the data needs to be scaled

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
\sphinxstylestrong{X\_scale} \textendash{} log scaler of magnitude of stft

\item[{Return type}] \leavevmode
ndarray

\end{description}\end{quote}
\subsubsection*{Examples}

Simple example for calculating scaling for each values.
Here values lower than 4.2 is scaled to 0 because it’s percentile
boundary was {[}4.2 9.{]}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{ex} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{array}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{7}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{9}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{6}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{scaler} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{Scaler}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{scaler}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{scale}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{X}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{ex}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+go}{[[0.         0.68273064 0.851306   0.25795466 1.        ]}
\PYG{g+go}{ [0.         0.25795466 0.         0.         0.48812467]]}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{description}



\end{fulllineitems}

\index{to\_mono() (in module preprocess.utility)@\spxentry{to\_mono()}\spxextra{in module preprocess.utility}}

\chapter{train package}

\section{train.model module}
\label{\detokenize{docs/source/train:module-train.model}}\label{\detokenize{docs/source/train:train-model-module}}\index{train.model (module)@\spxentry{train.model}\spxextra{module}}\index{Generalised\_Recurrent\_Model (class in train.model)@\spxentry{Generalised\_Recurrent\_Model}\spxextra{class in train.model}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{docs/source/train:train.model.Generalised_Recurrent_Model}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class }}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{train.model.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{Generalised\_Recurrent\_Model}}}{\emph{nb\_features}, \emph{nb\_frames}, \emph{nb\_layers}, \emph{hidden\_size}, \emph{bidirectional=False}, \emph{mixture\_mean=None}, \emph{mixture\_scale=None}, \emph{label\_mean=None}, \emph{activation\_function='relu'}, \emph{recurrent\_layer='lstm'}}{}
Bases: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{torch.nn.modules.module.Module}}

Generalised Model for neural networks with recurrent layers.

The structure of the Model is:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Fully Connected Layer} Dimensionality Reduction layer used for reducing the dimensionality of the input features. If recurrent layer features are too many it can have problems with long term dependencies (RNN will suffer from it the most).

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Recurrent Layer} It learns the time dependencies over the sample frames. LSTMs and GRUs will provide the best output, however RNN can be efficient and could provide good result over

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Fully Connected Layer} Dimensionality Expansion layer used for transforming the learned features to original shape.

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Variables}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{nb\_features}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{int}}) \textendash{} number of features(nb of bins) of input data.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{nb\_frames}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{int}}) \textendash{} number of frames or samples in each batch.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{nb\_layers}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{int}}) \textendash{} number of layers for recurrent layer.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{hidden\_size}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{int}}) \textendash{} number of hidden cells in the recurrent layer.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{mixture\_mean}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ndarray}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{, }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{shape}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{(}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{nb\_features}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{)}}) \textendash{} mean of mixture data.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{mixture\_scale}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ndarray}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{, }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{shape}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{(}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{nb\_features}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{)}}) \textendash{} scaled data of mixture.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{label\_mean}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ndarray}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{, }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{shape}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{(}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{nb\_features}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{)}}) \textendash{} mean of label data.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{activation\_function}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} activation function to use. “relu” by default, if “tanh” than tanh is used/

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{recurrent\_layer}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} recurrent layer to use. “lstm” by defalt, use “rnn” for RNN and “gru” for GRU.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}
\index{forward() (train.model.Generalised\_Recurrent\_Model method)@\spxentry{forward()}\spxextra{train.model.Generalised\_Recurrent\_Model method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{docs/source/train:train.model.Generalised_Recurrent_Model.forward}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{forward}}}{\emph{x}}{}
